intro.title: Winning major efficiencies in the fulfillment workflow
intro.subtitle: A workflow prone to costly errors
text: This project focused on the errors in the packing and shipping aspect of the retail business.

What drove the urgency in fixing these pain-points was a change in USPS policy that it would enforce accuracy of package weight and sizing. Until this point there was a margin of error being tolerated.
With a new clamp down, this translated to many thousands of dollars in monthly shipping adjustment charges that were really hard on retailers.

process.sectionTitle: A complex workflow with many edge cases
text: There was a lot of nuance in the fulfillment workflow that I had to wrap my head around. My task was to help Product and Engineering to envisage a more optimized solution. To add to the complexity, we had to support both legacy and new workflows together, seamlessly.
process.diagramImgCaption: Flow diagrams helped center coversations with stakeholders throughout the project lifecycle

text: I participated in many interviews with business owners and ethnographic research to build empathy and understanding of their daily process and needs.
The legacy workflow only enabled admin staff to purchase labels at the beginning of each fulfillment cycle.
A key point of discussion was enabling fulfillment staff to purchase labels at the point of packing. In this way there would be greater accuracy and ability to correct errors.
This change in approach put a lot of purchasing power in the hands of warehouse staff and necessitated trust that they would be economical in their decisions.

text: I workshopped ideas with Product at low resolution to get a handle on a core workflow that would enable fulfillment staff to refund pre-bought labels that were not accurate and purchase new ones on the fly.
Speed, accuracy, and efficiency is crucial to the new workflow being a success. We needed to rapidly draft many scenarios and edge cases to ensure we were addressing every need.
Framing a problem statement as a hmw question is a key step in helping the team generate ideas.
ideation.hmwProblemStatement: increase accuracy for purchasing shipping labels based on weight and dimensions, empower fulfillment staff to handle errors , and support both new and 'legacy' workflows
ideation.flowImgCaption: Low resolution capture of user needs

text: The research and ideation gave me a solid foundation from which to begin the wireframing process.
Typically, I would go through many iterations here, working from low resolution, presenting to stakeholders early and often. Continue to refine flows and resolution.
The interaction with this UI would primarily come from staff scanning product and functional barcodes. Keyboard and mouse fall-backs had to be included, but primarily I had to think 'barcode'.
I prepared clickable prototypes to walkthrough with shops so we could get early feedback
The details were important here. I used representative data that told a story for the most common flows used by shops daily.
With each project I ensured the presentation and consistency of the UI was executed at a higher level and was a better representation of the product.
settingsText: The fulfillment flow had many feature dependencies across the application. One of these was packaging presets, located within the application settings. This had to be redesigned to support the legacy and new workflows and work as a guardrail against errors. Through progressive enhancement I made improvements to the UI to bring up the standard within this settings section.
modalText: Some components needed additional focus and testing. For example, I created options for the 'features dependencies' modal that recommended shops activate other features for the best experience.
I had to work on the wording and UI for this a few times as it was not clear to shops what they needed to do, based on early user testing on this flow.

text: With complex state-management and many edge cases from both the legacy and new workflow, I setup my workstation to test a beta release with a barcode scanner.
Along with a thorough QA process, a few shops were recruited to trial the beta version and feedback on any UX or functional issues.

outcomes.sectionTitle: Major savings in time and money
text: When the beta stage was lifted and the new workflow was on general release, it took a few weeks for most shops to test and transition.
New help center documentation was released and account strategists were on-hand to advise the shops dealing with higher volumes of shipping.
After a few short months it was clear that the new workflow was out-performing the legacy version and saving retailers a lot of time and money.
wins: USPS adjustment charges reduced to near zero $$$
Admin time saved processing USPS adjustment charges
Efficient workflow error-handling reducing debugging time
Better platform for integrating UPS and Fedex
Full adoption rate across all shops

text: Local pickup was an important part of the workflow that I didn't fully capture. I would have caught the issues earlier by just asking why more.
